attributes.title: A SURVEY OF THE AVAILABILITY, PRICES AND AFFORDABILITY OF ESSENTIAL MEDICINES FOR TREATING CHILDHOOD CANCERS IN GHANA
attributes.description: To access the availability, pricing, and affordability of essential anti-neoplastic medicines in Ghana using the pediatric oncology unit at Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital as the anchor point.

summary.value: Studies suggest that childhood cancers in LMICs constitute 80% of the global burden of childhood cancers. The Essential Medicines List (EML) was developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) with the aim of improving accessibility, availability, and affordability. It further set a target of 80% availability and prices of not more than four times the international reference price across the public and private sectors.The study aimed to access the availability, pricing, and affordability of essential anti-neoplastic medicines in Ghana using the pediatric oncology unit at Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital as the anchor point.

attributes.title: Translation and Picture Naming: Assessing effects of iconicity in American Sign Language
attributes.description: In this study, we are exploring the retrieval and production of iconic and non-iconic signs by deaf ASL signers using Event-Related Potentials (ERPs) and behavioral reaction-time measures. We will compare the naming of pictures with iconic and non-iconic signs to the translation of English words that target the same iconic and non-iconic signs.

q1.value: Translation and Picture Naming: Assessing effects of iconicity in American Sign Language

q2.value: Meghan E. McGarry, Karen Emmorey, PHILLIP J HOLCOMB, Katherine J Midgley

q3.value: In this study, we are exploring the retrieval and production of iconic and non-iconic signs by deaf ASL signers using Event-Related Potentials (ERPs) and behavioral reaction-time measures. We will compare the naming of pictures with iconic and non-iconic signs to the translation of English words with the same iconic and non-iconic signs.

q4.value:
Iconic vs. Non-Iconic sign production: In prior work with iconic signs and picture naming, we found shorter naming times for iconic vs. non-iconic signs. Previous studies have found the same results with other sign languages (Baus and Costa 2015, Navarette et al. 2017, Pretato et al. 2018). We also found greater negativity during the N400 window for iconic sign production compared to non-iconic sign production in a previous study (McGarry et al, under review). We expect to replicate these results in this study. 
1.	If iconicity effects are associated with the lexical retrieval process itself, then similar behavioral and ERP effects should be found for both the translation and picture naming tasks (i.e., reduced reaction time and increased negativity during the N400 epoch for iconic vs. non-iconic signs).
2.	However, the iconicity effects observed during picture naming could be due to the fact that the features depicted by an iconic sign can be mapped to the visual features of the picture. For example, the extended index and middle fingers of the ASL sign SCISSORS map to the blades of the scissors seen in a picture, whereas non-iconic signs do not depict visual features of a picture. If the RT and ERP effects observed for picture naming are driven by the relationship between pictures and iconic signs, then iconicity may not have the same effect for the translation task because the English words bear no resemblance to the ASL signs.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Design: Participants will be presented with 88 black and white line drawings and 88 printed English words. Participants will be asked to name pictures and translate words in ASL. The study is administered in a single session consisting of two blocks: a translation block and a picture-naming block. The translation block is always presented first. Though the same items are presented in both blocks, the items are pseudorandomized within the block and presented in different orders.
1.	Translation: In the translation task, the participant will see 88 printed English words, and will be asked to translate the word into ASL. After naming each item, the participant indicates readiness to proceed to the next trial by holding down the spacebar.
2.	Picture-naming: Participants will see the same 88 concepts as black and white line-drawings, and are asked to name the picture in ASL. 

Stimuli: Critical targets were selected from an existing database of ASL signs with well-established English translations and from a lab database of prototypical, consistently-named pictures corresponding to the signs. The pictures used in this study were previously used in a prior study investigating iconicity (McGarry et al., under review). Signs were determined to be iconic if they were received a rating of 3.7 or higher and non-iconic if they received a rating of 2.5 or lower (as assessed by hearing non-signers on a scale of one to seven, where one was not at all iconic and 7 was very iconic). Iconicity ratings were retrieved from the ASL-Lex database (Caselli, Sevcikova Sehyr, Cohen-Goldberg & Emmorey, 2017).

q9.value: The study is administered in a single session consisting of two blocks: a translation block and a picture-naming block. The translation block is always presented first. Though the same items are presented in both blocks, the items are pseudorandomized within the block and presented in different orders.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Existing ERP data has been collected from 8 subjects. This data has not been processed and combined together to create a grand mean (a summary of the combined effects present in the participants brainwaves). Thus, no conclusions can be drawn about the existence of any data patterns at this time.

question.value:
Pre-selection: Deaf participants must be native/early signers of ASL (defined as individuals who began to sign prior to the age of seven).  All participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal vision, no history of a neurological condition, and provide consent in accordance with approved IRB protocols.

Data collection: Data from 24 deaf participants will take place at the NeuroCognition Lab. Participants will be fitted with an elastic cap (Electro-Cap) with 29 active electrodes. Saline gel (Electro-Gel) will be injected into electrodes to maintain impedances below 2.5 k. EEG will be amplified with SynAmsRT amplifiers (Neuroscan-Compumedics) with a bandpass of DC to 100 Hz and sampled continuously at 500 Hz.

Procedure
Task: Participants will receive instructions in both ASL and written English. Each trial will comprise a fixation cross (presented for 800ms), followed by a stimulus (word or picture) for 300ms.  Participants will name or translate the stimulus. The stimulus is followed by a screen with the text ‘click to continue’. Participants will then press to advance to the next trial.

Lists: Each participant will see all 88 trials first in the translation task then in the picture-naming task. Forty-four pictures/words targeting iconic signs and 44 picture/words targeting non-iconic signs are included to create the iconicity manipulation. All participants will complete the picture-naming task after the translational task, so as to avoid the potential of recalling the picture when performing the translational task and thereby influencing those results.

ERPs: ERPs will be time-locked to the presentation of the picture or word, and will be averaged over a 900 ms epoch. This epoch will include a 100 ms pre-stimulus-onset baseline, and will be processed with a 15 Hz low-pass filter at 15 sites (the same sites as in McGarry et al., submitted).

q13.value: Data will be collected from 24 native or early ASL signers. Data collection will be terminated once there are 24 useable participants following artifact rejection.

q14.value: A group of this size matches that of our earlier investigation using the same stimuli and task (McGarry et al., under review), where we found significant results in electrophysiological measures.

question.value:
Independent variables
1.	Iconicity (high, low): within subjects
2.	Stimuli type (picture, word): within subjects

Dependent variables
1.	Behavioral: response times for production, captured by recording the time elapsed between stimuli presentation and key release to begin signing.
2.	ERPs: Amplitude of N400 (lexico-semantic processing)

Confirmatory analyses

Behavioral: Behavioral results will be analyzed with R Linear Mixed Effects models. A model will be created for both the picture-naming condition and the translation condition (including iconicity, image complexity, image prototypicality, ASL frequency and English frequency as fixed effects in both) and random effects of participants and items.

ERPs: Mean N400 amplitude will be measured between 300 and 600ms in accordance with our prior picture naming study (McGarry et al., submitted), although an earlier (200-300ms) and later (600-800ms) epoch may be added if visual inspection of the waveforms reveals that effects onset earlier or later. Greenhouse-Geisser corrections will be applied to all interactional ERP analyses. 
         To analyze the effects of iconicity on ERP components, we will use an ANOVA with the following factors: Iconicity (Iconic, Non-iconic), Laterality (Left, Midline, Right), and Anteriority (Prefrontal, Frontal, Central, Parietal, Occipital). ANOVAs will be conducted for the picture-naming and for the translational conditions.

q22.value:
Participants will be excluded if 
•	They fail to name pictures (in the picture-naming blocks) or translate English words (in the translation blocks) for a large number of trials (>20%) 
•	A significant proportion (>30% of a given condition) of their ERP data are contaminated by artifact

Trials will be excluded 
•	From behavioral data if reaction times are too slow (over 2.5 SD above mean for each participant) or too fast (shorter than 300ms). 
•	From ERP data if contaminated by artifact (blink, drift, block, etc.)
•	From all data if incorrectly named or translated (determined by deviation from established correct/reasonable responses)

attributes.title: Gratitude and COVID-19
attributes.description: The relationship of a brief gratitude induction on COVID-19 related behavioral intentions and attitudes

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Gratitude and COVID-19.  A study examining the effects of a brief induction of gratitude onbehaviors and attitudes related to COVID-19

sample.value:
Data was collected on April 3rd, 2020. However, at the time of writing of this pre-registration (April 6th), data has not been analyzed.

An a priori power analysis conducted with G*Power indicated that we needed a minimum sample size of 159 to detect a medium effect size (d = .5) at alpha = .05 and power = 80% for three groups. Given that we were allocated a budget of $600 for this study, we decided to collect more than 159 participants and recruited as many participants as our budget could allow, which amounted to 400 participants.

With 400 participants, alpha = .05, and power = 80%, a sensitivity analysis conducted with G*Power indicated we can detect a minimum effect size of d = .31.

analyses.value:
Emotion Intensity 
- We will conduct a mixed ANOVA for emotion condition on gratitude intensity (an average of gratitude and appreciativeness), happiness intensity (an average of happy and content), and use post-hoc LSD tests to examine differences. 
- We expect to find gratitude (and to a lesser degree happiness) elevated in the gratitude condition and happiness elevated in the happiness condition (as per our usual findings in our published studies using these inductions).

For all DVs (listed above)
We will conduct a one-way ANOVA using emotion condition on the DV, with contrast analyses between gratitude and the combined of conditions neutral and happiness.

Mediation models
For all significant contrasts, we will conduct a mediation model. The predictor will be condition (0 = happiness/neutral combined, 1 = gratitude), the outcome variable will be the DV, and the mediator will be gratitude intensity.

outliers.value: We will exclude for insufficient or nonsensical responses to the writing task (e.g., “THIS WAS GOOD.” We will also exclude non-US participants.

dependent.value:
- Donation behavior
- Appropriateness Social Distancing/Resource Hoarding (9 questions)
- Behavioral Intentions (3 questions)

conditions.value: Participants were randomly assigned to three conditions: neutral, gratitude, happiness/amusement. See below for power analysis.

hypothesis.value: How does a brief induction of gratitude affect behaviors and attitudes related to COVID-19?

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Whereas we predict that people in the friendship jealousy condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition, we also explore--but do not explicitly predict--that people in the control condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in everyday friend retention behavior than friend guarding . We test the exploratory prediction that currently-felt friendship jealousy ("jealousy" in the manipulation check) statistically mediates the relationship between condition and reported intent to engage in friend guarding (whereas neutrality, happiness, sadness, and anger do not). 

After running our pre-registered pilot (Preregistration for Study 11) and finding that (a) our manipulations did work and (b) our results strongly supported our pre-registered predictions, we now pre-register this Study (chronologically Study 12, likely Study 6 in the manuscript).

sample.value: A priori power analysis indicated that approximately 350 participants would be required for .80 power to detect small- to medium-sized effects (f = .15) in friend guarding between the two conditions, thus assessing our focal prediction.

analyses.value: A 2 (condition) x 2 [friendship maintenance behavior] mixed-factors ANOVA with follow-up comparisons specifically aiming to explore the prediction that there is greater reported intent to engage in friend guarding among Ps in the friendship jealousy versus the relatively neutral friend-related control condition. We will then run a mediation analysis (PROCESS Model 4) to explore the secondary prediction that currently-felt friendship jealousy ("jealousy" in the manipulation check) statistically mediates the relationship between condition and reported intent to engage in friend guarding (whereas neutrality, happiness, sadness, and anger do not).

outliers.value: We have several bot and attention checks built into the survey. Participants' data will be excluded from analyses for failing any of the below. First, Ps must write the names of a same-sex best friend and a same-sex acquaintance (e.g., John), and are told not to use only initials. Those Ps skipping this question or failing it (e.g., by using John and Mary, two names that are highly unlikely to both be same-sex) will be excluded. Second, Ps must respond to manipulations by writing. Ps whose replies are obviously not cogent (e.g., they are pasting text from previous questions, failing to connect to the prompt) will be excluded. Third, we also included an attention check item toward the end of the survey. (Asking Ps to write "ethnicity" in the text box below, with radio button choices being Sex/Gender, Ethnicity, Sexual orientation, and Age, with the Age choice including the text box for Ps to write in "ethnicity". Case matching was not required to pass this check. Those failing this attention check will be excluded. Fourth, we also have a manipulation check question directly following the manipulation. Related, Ps' replies to the manipulation also serve as a similar check. (a) We will analyze the data without excluding Ps based on these checks, first, as doing so simply adds noise to the data. (In our manipulation checks, we expect people in the friendship jealousy condition to feel greater friendship jealousy ["jealousy" in the survey] than those in the control condition. We expect people the in the control condition to feel a greater amount of aggregated neutrality and happiness than those in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition. Those in the friendship jealousy condition may also feel high levels of anger and/or sadness, emotions often concomitant with jealousy.) Additionally, (b) an RA blind to hypotheses and conditions will read all non-excluded responses to the manipulations and rate each on the degree of jealously, neutrality (lack of strong emotions), happiness, anger, sadness expressed in each response on a 7-point scale (1= not at all, 7 = very much). People reporting jealousy below 4 in the friendship jealousy condition and people reporting a 4 or above on negative emotionality (anger, sadness, jealousy) in the control condition will be excluded in ancillary analysis b1, and those whose RA-scored responses are below 4 on jealousy in the friendship jealousy condition or 4 or above on negative emotionality (anger, sadness, jealousy) in the control condition will be excluded in ancillary analysis b2.

dependent.value: Similar to Study 5b, behavioral intent to engage in friend guarding will be measured via items corresponding to four friend-guarding tactics (vigilance, monopolization, induce jealousy, possession signals) on a 7-point Likert-type scale. We do not include Self/Commitment Enhancement here because some of those items have theoretical overlap with everyday friend retention items. On the same scale, we also measure behavioral intent to engage in everyday friend retention behavior via five items used in Study 2, assessing five tactics of friend retention. (We don't use the social networks tactic and item, “Rely on other friends to help you through this rough patch", because it would not be sensical with the control condition manipulation.

conditions.value: Two conditions: Friendship jealousy, relatively neutral friend-related control.

hypothesis.value: Do people who are currently experiencing friendship jealousy report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding (i.e., aggregate of tactics: vigilance, monopolization, induce jealousy, possession signals) than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition (who may be feeling relatively more neutral and/or happiness; i.e., not strong negative emotions). Whereas we predict that people in the friendship jealousy condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition, we also explore--but do not explicitly predict--whether people in the control condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in everyday friend retention behavior than friend guarding behavior.

registration_responses.dependent: Similar to Study 5b, behavioral intent to engage in friend guarding will be measured via items corresponding to four friend-guarding tactics (vigilance, monopolization, induce jealousy, possession signals) on a 7-point Likert-type scale. We do not include Self/Commitment Enhancement here because some of those items have theoretical overlap with everyday friend retention items. On the same scale, we also measure behavioral intent to engage in everyday friend retention behavior via five items used in Study 2, assessing five tactics of friend retention. (We don't use the social networks tactic and item, “Rely on other friends to help you through this rough patch", because it would not be sensical with the control condition manipulation.
registration_responses.conditions: Two conditions: Friendship jealousy, relatively neutral friend-related control.
registration_responses.hypothesis: Do people who are currently experiencing friendship jealousy report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding (i.e., aggregate of tactics: vigilance, monopolization, induce jealousy, possession signals) than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition (who may be feeling relatively more neutral and/or happiness; i.e., not strong negative emotions). Whereas we predict that people in the friendship jealousy condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in friend guarding than people in the relatively neutral friend-related control condition, we also explore--but do not explicitly predict--whether people in the control condition will report greater behavioral intentions to engage in everyday friend retention behavior than friend guarding behavior.

attributes.title: COVIDiSTRESS: Stress and Personality
attributes.description: Here, we intend to analyze data from COVIDiSTRESS global survey (pre-registration can be found under the link: https://osf.io/2ftma/), and investigate the role of personality on levels of stress and loneliness.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:

Moderation Isolation Status, Number of people in same place and Perceived Stress: While in relative isolation, extroverts staying together in the same place with more adults are less stressed than extroverts staying alone.

> Hayes mediation and moderation analysis.

attributes.title: Work Engagement and Job Performance: A Meta-Analysis
attributes.description:
This meta-analysis will study the link between work engagement and job performance, and provide an up-to-date perspective. Therefore the questions are as follows:

1. What is the link between each of the three dimensions of work engagement and job performance?
2. What are some possible moderators of this relationship?

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Random effects model meta analyses, on the link between job performance and each of the three work engagement components, followed by moderator analyses, in each case.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A systematic review will be carried out, in order to identify and download all relevant studies. 
- The following databases will be searched: PsycINFO, Web of Knowledge, Proquest, Scopus, ScienceDirect
- All quantitative types of study designs reporting the relationship between work engagement and job performance (e.g., correlational studies, longitudinal studies, etc.) will be included 
- To be included in this analysis, studies have to meet four criteria:

1. Studies should be held in an organisational environment. All studies targeting students will be excluded, however we will include any samples of working students, as long as the research was conducted in an organizational environment.
2. Studies should report the level of work engagement, either as a global score, or any of its constituents.
3. Papers should include a measure of job performance. Both objective measures, and self-reports will be considered.
4. Studies should provide information regarding the strength of the association between work engagement and job performance, even if it does not the main objective of the study (i.e., in the form of a correlation matrix).

q11.value: All the identified studies which meet the set inclusion criteria will be included in this meta-analysis.

question.value:
We will consider studies which measure burnout with the UWES questionnair, as well as any other valid measure of the construct 

We will consider studies which measure both in-role and extra-role performance, measured both subjectively or objectively. 

The following moderators will be considered: type of performance (i.e., in-role, extra-role), type of performance report (i.e., subjective reports, objective reports), conceptualisation of work engagement considered (i.e., either as a standalone concept or opposite of burnout)  and the participant occupation.

Individual study data will be pooled, effect sizes being calculated from the data, based on the sample and correlation values. The results will be converted into Fisher's Z, to for the non-normal distribution of Pearson’s r. For the instances in which the same construct reports multiple measures, statistical independence will be ensured by calculating an overall relationship, with one effect size per independent sample (Card, 2015). The Z’s (in other words, the standardised effect sizes) will then be weighted with the respective sample size and used to create a weighted mean Z. A random-effects meta-analysis will be conducted, using the metafor package in R (Viechtbauer, 2010). Heterogeneity will be assessed using a Q-test, T values and I² values. It will be considered meaningful for a significant Q-test result and an I² value greater or equal to 75%. A one-study-removed sensitivity analysis will be employed for detecting any potential outliers, or any study majorly influencing the obtained results. Lastly, funnel plots will be examined to determine the existence of publication bias.

q20.value: A one-study-removed sensitivity analysis will be employed for detecting any potential outliers, or any study majorly influencing the obtained results.

attributes.title: Acetaminophen, Inflammation, Disgust, and Learning Amendment
attributes.description: This is a pre-registration amending a previous pre-registration in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.

summary.value: This pre-registration is amending preregistration titled, Acetaminophen, Inflammation, Disgust, and Learning (https://osf.io/d4zkm/). In the original registration we had pre-registered a final sample size of N = 300, methods, data analysis plan, and hypotheses. Although we had every intention to reach our pre-registered sample size, due to the global COVID-19 pandemic all data collection had to stop. We have also decided that we cannot continue the study when the pandemic is over because our key variables of interest are likely to be affected by the pandemic (e.g. relationship between disgust sensitivity and inflammation). Therefore, we will end the study at our current sample size of N = 222. Before deciding to stop the study due to the pandemic, no member of the research team has analyzed the data. We will analyze the data using our original data analysis plan from the original preregistration.

attributes.title: The Worst Motive Fallacy
attributes.description: To test replicability of effect reported in Walmsley and O'Madagain (this page), we will rerun the experiment with an expanded number of vignettes and participants, and add vignette as a random intercept to the model.

item1.value: In Walmsley and O'Madagain "The Worst Motive Fallacy" we found that participants were significantly inclined to expect an agent in a story to act on the worst of two motives we described the agent as having. We want to replicate this in the following study.

item2.value:
In our replication, we will use 12 vignettes instead of just the 4 from our original study (we will replicate the effect of the 4, and add 8 more). This will increase the diversity of the vignettes, and also allow us to include vignette as a random effect in the model for the study (a random effect with four levels is not optimal). 

Also, the effect we found before was significant but not highly. If the effect is real, it should replicate.

item3.value: n/a. effects reported through model comparison

item4.value: n/a. effects reported through model comparison

item16.value: We are using three times as many stimuli as in the original, so we want to increase the sample size sufficiently to include vignette as a random effect, hence multiplying the sample size by 3.

item24.value: We are replicating the original four vignettes but also eight more, to increase the plausibility of our conclusion (that the effect is independent of the context). The additional vignettes may affect the outcome. We are also including vignette as a random effect in the model, which is a sound approach now that we have twelve vignettes - this may also affect the outcome.

item25.value: None. We have made the prediction that our effect is independent of context - therefore we should be able to find the effect across new vignettes with the same basic structure. If we pilot these vignettes to "see if they work", this would bias our selection of vignettes unreasonably in our favor.

item26.value:
Participants are given three very easy 'attention questions' at the outset of the study, and those who do not answer all three correctly are excluded on the assumption that they are not paying attention.
Participants who do not complete the study are excluded.

item27.value: Include random effect of vignette, whereas vignette was included as a fixed effect in our original study. The inclusion of vignette as a random effect is to take a more conservative approach to the claim that the effect is not dependent on the vignette chosen.

item28.value: The study will replicate successfully if, for the original vignettes as well as new vignettes with the same basic structure, participants significantly expect the agent in the vignette to act on the worst of two competing motives she has.

attributes.title: Pronomen 'Hen' och ansiktsigenkänning
attributes.description: Ett examensprojekt som berör påverkan av pronomen 'hen' på ansiktsigenkänning.

q2.value:
Båda hypoteserna i studien är enkelriktade:

Hypotes 1: Avfärdningstiden vid ansiktsigenkänning kommer att påverkas av kongruensen mellan könsinformationen som finns i pronomenet (kvinnligt/manligt) och könsinformationen i ansiktet (kvinnligt/manligt), där ansikten av motsatt kön kommer att avfärdas snabbare jämfört med de av samma kön som det som söks. 

Hypotes 2: Avfärdningstiden vid ett könsneutralt pronomen tros bli konsekvent fördröjd i och med att ansiktsigenkänningen inte får någon hjälp av ett manligt eller kvinnligt pronomen (den kontextbaserade informationen), utan främst påverkas av den ansiktsbaserade informationen.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
Studien är utformad som en inomgruppsdesign där deltagarna kommer att genomföra ett och samma ansiktsigenkänningstest med randomiserade omgångar. 

Ett ansiktsigenkänningstest kommer att genomföras på en dator. Testet består i första hand av instruktioner kring utförande och ett presenterat pronomen (‘han/hon/hen’). Totalt består testet av tre olika bilder med androgyna ansikten som är morphade med 50/50 av manliga- och kvinnliga drag, en bild avsedd för respektive testomgång. För varje omgång följer det sedan 20 stycken olika ansikten som är morphade mellan ett manligt och kvinnligt ansikte, varav 9 stycken med dominerande drag åt det kvinnliga, 9 stycken dominerande drag åt det manliga och 2 stycken motsvarar det rätta ansiktet som studerats (targetansiktet). Ansiktena kommer att vara av samma färgkategori (caucasian) med ett svartvitt filter då färgskillnader snabbt kan upptäckas och kategoriseras (Levin & Beale, 2000).

q7.value: Alla deltagare kommer att få genomföra ett ansiktsigenkänningstest bestående av tre randomiserade omgångar. Inom dessa omgångar kommer samtliga bilder (som ska avfärdas/bekräftas) också att vara randomiserade.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
REKRYTERING AV STICKPROV:

Deltagarna kommer att rekryteras utifrån ett bekvämlighetsurval genom utlysta deltagarplatser via sociala medier. För att kunna delta i undersökningen kommer deltagarna att informeras om att det är viktigt att ha god- eller korrigerad syn med glasögon/linser, i och med att testet utspelar sig framför en skärm, samt att ha god läsförståelse på svenska. På grund av att testet är särskilt utformat för att genomföras på en dator har deltagarna även blivit informerade om att det är viktigt att de endast använder en sådan plattform.

DATAINSAMLING:

Deltagarna kommer enskilt att få utföra ansiktsigenkänningstestet bestående av tre randomiserade omgångar. Först kommer deltagaren att få  information om vad undersökningen går ut på, att deltagandet i undersökningen är frivilligt, samt att uppgifter är anonymiserade och sparas konfidentiellt. I samband med detta ska deltagaren även godkänna att de tagit del av informationen och lämnar sitt samtycke för sitt deltagande. De kommer även att få medge att de genomför testet på en dator med tangentbord då det är viktigt för genomförandet av testet. Därefter följer instruktioner om hur testet är utformat och på vilket sätt det ska genomföras, där det framgår att de kommer att få studera ett ansikte under 10 sekunder och därefter få i uppgift att avfärda/bekräfta flera ansikten så fort som möjligt, ett ansikte i taget, utifrån överensstämmelsen med det ansikte som har studerats. För att ange att ansiktet de ser motsvarar det som söks kommer de att behöva trycka på tangent “J” och för att ange att det inte motsvarar det som söks kommer de att behöva trycka på tangent “F”. När deltagaren har tagit del av denna information kommer den att få genomföra en testomgång. 

Efter testomgången kommer deltagaren att få instruktioner om att den verkliga omgången kommer att börja och att de ska studera ansiktet (presenterat med ett pronomen ‘han/hon/hen') i 5 sekunder. Totalt ska deltagaren genomföra tre randomiserade omgångar (en med respektive pronomen). Därefter kommer deltagaren att få se ansiktet (target) under 5 sekunder. Efter detta kommer det att finnas ett fixeringskors på skärmen som deltagaren kan fokusera på innan det börjar komma upp ett ansikte åt gången som deltagaren ska välja att avfärda eller bekräfta så snabbt som möjligt, genom att trycka på två tangenter på datorn: en som motsvarar att det är en matchning och en som motsvarar att det inte är en matchning. Efter att hela serien av 20 ansikten är besvarad är en omgång genomförd. 

Efter genomförandet av alla tre omgångar kommer deltagarna få svara på ett antal frågor som avser att täcka in intressanta bakgrundsvariabler: deltagarnas uppfattningar om prestation på testet, ålder, könsidentitet och attityd till ordet hen. Frågorna kring attityd till ordet hen är utformade utifrån frågeformuläret som inkludeats i tidigare studie av Gustafsson et al. (2015).

q11.value: Stickprovets storlek har beräknats till 291 st deltagare (se motivering). Vi kommer därför att eftersträva att få med minst 320 st deltagare för att säkra att tillräckligt många slutför undersökningen.

q12.value: Stickprovets storlek har utifrån en a priori effektanalys med G * Power3 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) estimerats till 291 st deltagare för att få en power på 0,80. Beräkningarna är gjorda för att testa skillnaden mellan tre beroende gruppmedelvärden med ett f-test, en låg effektstorlek (d = 0,15) och en alfanivå på 0,05.

q13.value: Datainsamlingen kommer att avslutas antingen när antalet undersökningsdeltagare möter den beräknade stickprovsstorleken eller när tiden för datainsamling är slut (senast den 12/4/2020).

question.value:
OBEROENDE VARIABLER:

1. Matchande pronomen (gentemot könsinformation i bilden): 
Han + Han
Hon + Hon

2. Icke-matchande pronomen (gentemot könsinformation i bilden).
Han + Hon
Hon + Han

BEROENDE VARIABEL: 
Avfärdningstid vid presenterat ansikte (matchning/icke-matchning).

KONTROLLVARIABEL:
Antal rätt/fel vid avfärdning/bekräftande (för att mäta engagemang/motivation).

BAKGRUNDSVARIABLER:
Uppfattningar om prestation och engagemang vid deltagande.
Ålder och könsidentitet. 
Tidigare uppfattningar och attityd till hen (Gustafsson et al., 2015).
Data kommer först att beskrivas deskriptivt, med medelvärden och standardavvikelse för den beroende variabeln: svarstid.

Hypotes 1 analyseras med ett t-test för tiden det tar att avfärda ett icke-matchande ansikte i jämförelse med tiden det tar att avfärda ett ansikte som matchar det kön som söks (manligt/kvinnligt). 

Hypotes 2 analyseras med en envägs beroende ANOVA avseende avfärdningstid vid matchande (kön+ansikte), avfärdningstid vid icke-matchande (kön+ansikte) och avfärdningstid vid Hen-pronomen. Detta kommer även att kompletteras med ett post hoc test för beroende mätningar.

q18.value: Insamlad data kommer inte att behöva transformeras för att kunna genomföra lämpliga analyser i och med att den beroende variabeln (avfärdningstid) är på kvotdatanivå och de oberoende variabelerna (matchande/icke matchande pronomen) är på kategoridatanivå.

q19.value: Vi kommer att studera vilka p-värden (utifrån alfanivån p<0.05) vi får för att kunna dra slutsatser om statistisk signifikans.

q20.value:
Ett tröskelvärde för bortfall utifrån antalet rätt/fel svar på testet behöver rimligtvis vara på minst 50% rätt svar i och med att det annars lika gärna hade kunnat vara en chansning, det skulle dock vara orimligt att sätta ett tröskelvärde på 100% rätt svar i och med att det behöver finnas utrymme för misstag. I och med att det finns 2 targets per testomgång och tre omgångar totalt, så  är det totala antalet rätt som deltagaren kan få 6 st. Utifrån detta har det därför bedömts rimligt att ha minst 4 av 6 möjliga rätt som ett tröskelvärde. 

I tidigare studie av Baudouin och Tiberghien (2002) har tröskelvärdet för den beroende variabeln avfärdningstid baseras på de värden som faller inom ramen för två standardavvikelser från medelvärdet. På grund av skillnaden i utformande av detta test för ansiktsigenkänning har tröskelvärdet istället bestämts utifrån “three sigma rule”, där värden som befinner sig utanför tre standardavvikelser från medelvärdet exkluderats.

Båda hypoteserna i studien är enkelriktade:

Hypotes 1: Avfärdningstiden vid ansiktsigenkänning kommer att påverkas av kongruensen mellan könsinformationen som finns i pronomenet (kvinnligt/manligt) och könsinformationen i ansiktet (kvinnligt/manligt), där ansikten av motsatt kön kommer att avfärdas snabbare jämfört med de av samma kön som det som söks. 

Hypotes 2: Avfärdningstiden vid ett könsneutralt pronomen tros bli konsekvent fördröjd i och med att ansiktsigenkänningen inte får någon hjälp av ett manligt eller kvinnligt pronomen (den kontextbaserade informationen), utan främst påverkas av den ansiktsbaserade informationen.

registration_responses.q6.question:
Studien är utformad som en inomgruppsdesign där deltagarna kommer att genomföra ett och samma ansiktsigenkänningstest med randomiserade omgångar. 

Ett ansiktsigenkänningstest kommer att genomföras på en dator. Testet består i första hand av instruktioner kring utförande och ett presenterat pronomen (‘han/hon/hen’). Totalt består testet av tre olika bilder med androgyna ansikten som är morphade med 50/50 av manliga- och kvinnliga drag, en bild avsedd för respektive testomgång. För varje omgång följer det sedan 20 stycken olika ansikten som är morphade mellan ett manligt och kvinnligt ansikte, varav 9 stycken med dominerande drag åt det kvinnliga, 9 stycken dominerande drag åt det manliga och 2 stycken motsvarar det rätta ansiktet som studerats (targetansiktet). Ansiktena kommer att vara av samma färgkategori (caucasian) med ett svartvitt filter då färgskillnader snabbt kan upptäckas och kategoriseras (Levin & Beale, 2000).
registration_responses.q10.question:
REKRYTERING AV STICKPROV:

Deltagarna kommer att rekryteras utifrån ett bekvämlighetsurval genom utlysta deltagarplatser via sociala medier. För att kunna delta i undersökningen kommer deltagarna att informeras om att det är viktigt att ha god- eller korrigerad syn med glasögon/linser, i och med att testet utspelar sig framför en skärm, samt att ha god läsförståelse på svenska. På grund av att testet är särskilt utformat för att genomföras på en dator har deltagarna även blivit informerade om att det är viktigt att de endast använder en sådan plattform.

DATAINSAMLING:

Deltagarna kommer enskilt att få utföra ansiktsigenkänningstestet bestående av tre randomiserade omgångar. Först kommer deltagaren att få  information om vad undersökningen går ut på, att deltagandet i undersökningen är frivilligt, samt att uppgifter är anonymiserade och sparas konfidentiellt. I samband med detta ska deltagaren även godkänna att de tagit del av informationen och lämnar sitt samtycke för sitt deltagande. De kommer även att få medge att de genomför testet på en dator med tangentbord då det är viktigt för genomförandet av testet. Därefter följer instruktioner om hur testet är utformat och på vilket sätt det ska genomföras, där det framgår att de kommer att få studera ett ansikte under 10 sekunder och därefter få i uppgift att avfärda/bekräfta flera ansikten så fort som möjligt, ett ansikte i taget, utifrån överensstämmelsen med det ansikte som har studerats. För att ange att ansiktet de ser motsvarar det som söks kommer de att behöva trycka på tangent “J” och för att ange att det inte motsvarar det som söks kommer de att behöva trycka på tangent “F”. När deltagaren har tagit del av denna information kommer den att få genomföra en testomgång. 

Efter testomgången kommer deltagaren att få instruktioner om att den verkliga omgången kommer att börja och att de ska studera ansiktet (presenterat med ett pronomen ‘han/hon/hen') i 5 sekunder. Totalt ska deltagaren genomföra tre randomiserade omgångar (en med respektive pronomen). Därefter kommer deltagaren att få se ansiktet (target) under 5 sekunder. Efter detta kommer det att finnas ett fixeringskors på skärmen som deltagaren kan fokusera på innan det börjar komma upp ett ansikte åt gången som deltagaren ska välja att avfärda eller bekräfta så snabbt som möjligt, genom att trycka på två tangenter på datorn: en som motsvarar att det är en matchning och en som motsvarar att det inte är en matchning. Efter att hela serien av 20 ansikten är besvarad är en omgång genomförd. 

Efter genomförandet av alla tre omgångar kommer deltagarna få svara på ett antal frågor som avser att täcka in intressanta bakgrundsvariabler: deltagarnas uppfattningar om prestation på testet, ålder, könsidentitet och attityd till ordet hen. Frågorna kring attityd till ordet hen är utformade utifrån frågeformuläret som inkludeats i tidigare studie av Gustafsson et al. (2015).
registration_responses.q14.question:

BEROENDE VARIABEL: 
Avfärdningstid vid presenterat ansikte (matchning/icke-matchning).

Antal rätt/fel vid avfärdning/bekräftande (för att mäta engagemang/motivation).

BAKGRUNDSVARIABLER:
Uppfattningar om prestation och engagemang vid deltagande.
Ålder och könsidentitet. 
Tidigare uppfattningar och attityd till hen (Gustafsson et al., 2015).
registration_responses.q16.question: Data kommer först att beskrivas deskriptivt, med medelvärden och standardavvikelse för den beroende variabeln: svarstid.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Hypotes 1 analyseras med ett t-test för tiden det tar att avfärda ett icke-matchande ansikte i jämförelse med tiden det tar att avfärda ett ansikte som matchar det kön som söks (manligt/kvinnligt). 

Hypotes 2 analyseras med en envägs beroende ANOVA avseende avfärdningstid vid matchande (kön+ansikte), avfärdningstid vid icke-matchande (kön+ansikte) och avfärdningstid vid Hen-pronomen. Detta kommer även att kompletteras med ett post hoc test för beroende mätningar.

attributes.title: Association between Diastolic Dysfunction and Postoperative Outcomes After Renal Transplantation
attributes.description:
Background/Significance: 

Cardiovascular disease remains the most common cause of death after kidney transplantation worldwide, with the highest event rate in the early postoperative period1. The current AHA cardiac risk stratification of patients undergoing renal transplantation does not address Diastolic dysfunction (DD)2. Nearly 50% of heart failure patients are characterized by normal systolic and abnormal diastolic function3, 4. Several studies reporting data on perioperative diastolic dysfunction have observed adverse outcomes among patients undergoing cardiac and vascular surgery as well as in critically ill patients5, 6. Not surprisingly, the diagnosis of diastolic dysfunction carries profound implications for risk stratification7 and appropriate patient management8 in the perioperative period. Despite the expected significant implications of the presence diastolic dysfunction on outcomes, these outcomes have not been investigated in patients undergoing renal transplantation. To address this question, we designed an observational study to assess whether preoperative diastolic dysfunction as measured by transthoracic echocardiography is associated with worse postoperative outcomes in patient undergoing renal transplantation. 

Hypothesis: 
We hypothesize that diastolic dysfunction may be an important risk factor for adverse postoperative outcomes in patients undergoing renal transplantation surgery.

Aim:
To determine if preoperative diastolic function, as defined by the ASE criteria, is associated with postoperative Major Adverse Events (AE) in a cohort of patients undergoing renal transplantation surgery.

Specific Design and Procedures:
Patients over 18 years of age undergoing kidney transplants between 01/2011- 08/2019 with a preoperative transthoracic echo within a year of transplant will be included in the study. The exclusion criteria include baseline EF<55%, heart kidney transplants, pre-operative non-sinus rhythms, mitral valvular disorders (any degree of mitral stenosis or moderate to severe mitral regurgitation), mitral annular calcification, aortic valve disorders (moderate to severe aortic stenosis or regurgitation). 
Data will be collected from the electronic medical records or institutional MPOG and SRTR databases. The variables pertinent to diastolic function will be abstracted by review of the transthoracic echography reports and classified based on the criteria of the ASE guidelines9.


Methods of analysis, including statistical techniques:
The primary aim of the study is to evaluate if diastolic function (DD)
is associated with poor postoperative outcomes. Per the ASE guidelines patients will adjudicated for the present or absence of DD.  Our primary study endpoint is the occurrence of postoperative Major Adverse Events (MAE). MAEs are defined as a composite of in hospital mortality, myocardial infarction, pneumonia, stroke, need for postoperative dialysis, prolonged postoperative mechanical ventilation (postoperative mechanical ventilation >24 hours postoperatively) and atrial fibrillation. Our secondary endpoints will be 30-day and 1-year mortality. 

Variables that will be recorded are listed in the attached document. Briefly, following variables will be recorded:
Age, gender, race, weight, BMI, smoking status, ASA status, COPD requiring oxygen at baseline, selected preoperative medications, duration of surgery, intraoperative crystalloids, intraoperative colloids, intraoperative blood product transfusion.

Statistics:
Patients will be divided in two groups based on the preoperative presence of diastolic dysfunction. Baseline characteristics will be compared between the two groups. Categorical variables will be described using frequency distribution. Medians with interquartile ranges (IQR) and means with standard deviations (SD) will be used to describe continuous variables. Chi-square or two-sample Student’s t-test will be used to compare categorical and continuous variables between the two groups , respectively. 

For the primary endpoint, in univariate analysis, we will compare the incidence of postoperative complications (MAE) between the groups using simple logistic regression. To account for potential confounders, we will use multivariable logistic-regression.  The model will adjust for a priori defined potential confounders such as age, gender, BMI, and ASA physical status. The model will also adjust for variables that are thought to be associated with outcomes such as smoking status, medications (beta blockers, ACE inhibitors), COPD, operative time and ischemia time.

In secondary analysis, we will fit the same regression model to estimate the associations of diastolic dysfunction with the secondary endpoints of 30 day and 1-year mortality. A two-sided alpha level of 0.05 will be required for significance. All statistical analyses will be performed using STATA version 13.0 or R statistical software package (version 3.0.2). 

Sample size considerations. Based on prior reports, we expect an incidence of diastolic dysfunction among patients presenting for kidney transplantation to be approximately 34%10. Assuming a MAE incidence of 15% in patients with DD, an assuming a power of 80%, to detect a 10% difference in MAE between patients with a without diastolic dysfunction, a total sample size of 397 patients would be required. 






 
Table 1:  List of echocardiographic variables to be measured.
Serial Number	ECHO variable
1	LVEF
2	Transmitral  E velocity
3	Transmitral  A velocity
4	Septal e’ velocity

5	Lateral e’ velocity
6	TR velocity
7	Left atrial volume index
8	LV longitudinal strain
9	RV longitudinal strain
10	RV  EF
11	TAPSE



 
References:


1.	Hart A, Weir MR, Kasiske BL. Cardiovascular risk assessment in kidney transplantation. Kidney Int. 2015;87:527-534
2.	Lentine KL, Costa SP, Weir MR, Robb JF, Fleisher LA, Kasiske BL, Carithers RL, Ragosta M, Bolton K, Auerbach AD, Eagle KA, American Heart Association Council on the Kidney in Cardiovascular D, Council on Peripheral Vascular D, American Heart A, American College of Cardiology F. Cardiac disease evaluation and management among kidney and liver transplantation candidates: A scientific statement from the american heart association and the american college of cardiology foundation: Endorsed by the american society of transplant surgeons, american society of transplantation, and national kidney foundation. Circulation. 2012;126:617-663
3.	Soufer R, Wohlgelernter D, Vita NA, Amuchestegui M, Sostman HD, Berger HJ, Zaret BL. Intact systolic left ventricular function in clinical congestive heart failure. Am J Cardiol. 1985;55:1032-1036
4.	Topol EJ, Traill TA, Fortuin NJ. Hypertensive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy of the elderly. N Engl J Med. 1985;312:277-283
5.	Flu WJ, van Kuijk JP, Hoeks SE, Kuiper R, Schouten O, Goei D, Elhendy A, Verhagen HJ, Thomson IR, Bax JJ, Fleisher LA, Poldermans D. Prognostic implications of asymptomatic left ventricular dysfunction in patients undergoing vascular surgery. Anesthesiology. 2010;112:1316-1324
6.	Mahmood F, Jainandunsing J, Matyal R. A practical approach to echocardiographic assessment of perioperative diastolic dysfunction. J Cardiothorac Vasc Anesth. 2012;26:1115-1123
7.	Halley CM, Houghtaling PL, Khalil MK, Thomas JD, Jaber WA. Mortality rate in patients with diastolic dysfunction and normal systolic function. Arch Intern Med. 2011;171:1082-1087
8.	O'Connell JB, Bristow MR. Economic impact of heart failure in the united states: Time for a different approach. J Heart Lung Transplant. 1994;13:S107-112
9.	Nagueh SF, Smiseth OA, Appleton CP, Byrd BF, 3rd, Dokainish H, Edvardsen T, Flachskampf FA, Gillebert TC, Klein AL, Lancellotti P, Marino P, Oh JK, Popescu BA, Waggoner AD. J Am Soc Echocardiogr. 2016;29:277-314
